A car is travelling along a road that has a uniform downhill gradient, as shown in Fig. 2.1
The car has a total mass of \(850\mathrm{kg}\). The angle of the road to the horizontal is \(7.5^{\circ}\)
Calculate the component of the weight of the car down the slope
component of weight = .........N

Calculate the distance the car travels from when the brakes are applied until the car comes to rest

1. the loss of kinetic energy of the car,
loss of kinetic energy = .........J
the work done by the resisting force of 4600N
work done = .........J

If only the 70N weight is moved, there is a maximum weight of student that can be determined using the arrangement shown in Fig. 3.1. State and explain **one** change that can be made to increase this maximum weight
A student is being weighed. The student, of weight \(W,\) stands \(0.30 \text{m}\) from end A of a uniform plank AB, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The plank has weight \(80 \text{N}\) and length \(2.0 \text{m}\). A pivot P supports the plank and is \(0.50 \text{m}\) from end A
A weight of \(70 \text{N}\) is moved to balance the weight of the student. The plank is in equilibrium when the weight is \(0.20 \text{m}\) from end B

extension = .........m

The same load is hung from a second wire of the same material. This wire is twice the length but the same volume as the first wire. State and explain how the extension of the second wire compares with that of the first wire
A wire of length \(1.70 \text{m}\) hangs vertically from a fixed point, as shown in Fig. 4.1

The wire has cross-sectional area \(5.74 \times 10^{-8} \text{m}^2\) and is made of a material that has a Young modulus of \(1.60 \times 10^{11} \text{Pa}\). A load of \(25.0 \text{N}\) is hung from the wire
The maximum possible current in the circuit is 2.0A. Calculate the minimum possible current
minimum current = .........A

A variable resistor is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1

The variable resistor is connected in series with a \(12\mathrm{V}\) power supply of negligible internal resistance, an ammeter and a \(6.0\Omega\) resistor. The resistance \(R\) of the variable resistor can be varied between 0 and \(12\Omega\)
The variable resistor in **(a)** is now connected as a potential divider, as shown in Fig. 5.3
